awd_abstract_narration:
This award will fund three meetings of a well-established series of summer Workshops in Geometric Topology, with the first to be held at Calvin College in Grand Rapids, MI, June 14-16, 2018. The award will also fund workshops at the University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee in 2019 and at Texas Christian University in Fort Worth, TX, in 2020. These workshops provide an annual opportunity for active researchers and graduate students in the mathematical field of geometric topology to interact in a setting that provides multiple tangible benefits, including:
1) attending the lectures of a principal speaker to receive an in-depth introduction to important current streams of research being performed by nationally-recognized experts,
2) learning about a breadth of other research activities by attending shorter talks given by the other workshop participants,
3) the opportunity to share their own work by giving talks in a congenial environment, and
4) important time for informal discussion and interaction among participants and with the principal speaker.
These workshops regularly feature participation and talks by members of underrepresented groups in mathematics, and, to further broaden the impact of the workshops, the talks of the principal speaker will be recorded and posted to the internet. The workshops also provide significant benefits to graduate students by providing a serious but informal research atmosphere in which they can meet and learn from others in the field. NSF funding will be used to cover the attendance costs of workshop participants.

More specifically, the workshops provide opportunities for geometric topologists to interact and share ideas, leading to research collaborations. Furthermore, the proposed workshops will continue the tradition of inviting each year a renowned principal speaker to provide a series of three lectures on a topic of his or her choice for the purpose of expanding the interests of the participants by having a nationally-recognized expert discuss an important area of current interest. The 2018 workshop will feature Andras Stipsicz of the Renyi Institute of Mathematics.  The web site for this workshop will be http://www.calvin.edu/~venema/workshop18/ .

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
NSF Grant DMS-1764311 funded the annual "Workshops in Geometric Topology" in the years 2018-2023; a no-cost extension allowed some unspent funds to help with the 2018 workshop as well. Nearly all funding was used to cover travel expenses of workshop participants, with most going to participants without other means of support. Graduate students and recent graduates as well as members of underrepresented groups were given special consideration for funding.

The Geometric Topology Workshops provide an annual opportunity for active researchers and graduate students to interact in a setting that provides multiple tangible benefits. Some of these benefits include attending the lectures of the principal speaker to receive an in-depth introduction to important current streams of research being performed by nationally recognized experts, learning about a breadth of other research activities by attending shorter talks given by the other workshop participants, sharing their own work by giving talks in a congenial environment, and engaging in informal discussion and interaction among participants and with the principal speaker. To further broaden the impact of the workshops, the talks of the principal speakers are recorded and posted to the workshop's YouTube channel https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCS5moV_cAAz0mHwk7Ezd42g . In 2021 and 2022, all talks were recorded and posted on the internet as well. There are currently 394 subscribers to the channel.

Calvin College hosted the 2018 workshop on their campus in Grand Rapids, Michigan. Andras Stipsicz of the Alfred Renyi Institute of Mathematics in Budapest, Hungary, delivered the principal lectures on invariants of knots and links. Among the 55 mathematicians attending the conference were 17 graduate students, 2 postdocs, and 3 undergraduate students. 23 contributed talks of twenty-minutes were given, 8 by students and 2 by postdocs.

The University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee hosted the 2019 workshop on their campus in Milwaukee, WI. Ciprian Manolescu of the University of California Los Angeles delivered the principal lectures on several different topics in geometric topology, including triangulations of manifolds, Seiberg-Witten theory, and Heegaard Floer homology. Among the 54 mathematicians attending the conference were 20 graduate students and 6 postdocs. In addition to Manolescu's lectures, there were 23 twenty-minute talks contributed by other workshop participants; 4 of those were by postdocs and 7 by graduate students.

The workshop was postponed in 2020 due to the COVID-19 pandemic.

The 2021 workshop was hosted virtually due to on-going concerns for participant safety due to COVID-19. Peter Bubenik of the University of Florida delivered the principal lectures on topological data analysis. The topics included summaries of persistence, the theory of topological data analysis, and multiple parameters. Among the 154 mathematicians registered for the conference were 14 postdocs, 43 graduate students, and 8 undergraduate students. In addition to Bubenik's talks, there were 28 contributed twenty-minute talks by other workshop participants, of which 6 were given by students and 5 by postdocs.

The 2022 workshop was hosted virtually due to on-going concerns for participant safety due to COVID-19. Jessica Purcell of Monash University delivered the principal lectures on hyperbolic geometry as a tool to study three manifolds and knots. Among the 223 mathematicians registered for the conference were 26 postdocs, 94 graduate students, 14 undergraduate students, and 3 un-specified student levels. In addition to Purcell's lectures, there were 43 contributed twenty-minute talks by other workshop participants, of which 17 were given by students and 7 by postdocs.

Colorado College hosted the 2023 workshop on their campus in Colorado Springs, CO. Andy Putman of the University of Notre Dame delivered the principal lectures on the topology of the moduli space of curves. Among the 41 mathematicians attending the conference were 20 students and 3 postdocs. In addition to Putman's lectures, there were 22 twenty-minute talks contributed by other workshop participants of which 10 were given by students and 3 by postdocs.

 

An archive of materials from past workshops can be found at http://faculty.tcu.edu/gfriedman/GTW_archive/ .
